message_1: Suppose a message "MATHEMATICS" is to be digitally signed using an RSA algorithm with a private key (d,n) = (17, 253). The corresponding public key is (e,n) = (13, 253). What is the digital signature of the message?
message_2:
To digitally sign the message "MATHEMATICS" using RSA, we first need to convert the message into a numerical representation. We can do this by assigning a numerical value to each letter (A=1, B=2, ..., Z=26). 

MATHEMATICS = 13 1 20 8 5 13 1 20 9 3 19

However, since n = 253, we need to make sure that the numerical representation of the message is less than n. To do this, we can combine the numerical values in pairs:

MA = 131, TH = 208, EM = 135, AT = 201, IC = 93, S = 19

Now, we can digitally sign each pair using the private key (d, n) = (17, 253) by raising each pair to the power of d modulo n:

Signature(MA) = 131^17 mod 253 = 106
Signature(TH) = 208^17 mod 253 = 131
Signature(EM) = 135^17 mod 253 = 208
Signature(AT) = 201^17 mod 253 = 135
Signature(IC) = 93^17 mod 253 = 201
Signature(S) = 19^17 mod 253 = 93

The digital signature of the message "MATHEMATICS" is:

106 131 208 135 201 93
